Gingerbread Oatmeal Cookies

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to a delightful journey into the world of baking with these Gingerbread Oatmeal Cookies! Perfectly spiced and bursting with the warm flavors of ginger and cinnamon, these cookies are not only a treat for your taste buds but also a wholesome snack, thanks to the addition of rolled oats. Whether you're preparing for the holiday season or simply craving a comforting dessert, this recipe combines the classic taste of gingerbread with the chewy texture of oatmeal, making it a versatile option for any occasion. With ingredients like molasses, brown sugar, and unsalted butter, each bite melts in your mouth, delivering a nostalgic flavor that evokes the spirit of cozy winter evenings. Plus, they're easy to whip up, requiring just a few simple steps. So, grab your mixing bowl and preheat your oven as we dive into this deliciously spiced recipe that will surely become a favorite in your home!

Ingredients

rolled oats

For a chewier texture, use old-fashioned rolled oats instead of quick oats. If you don't have rolled oats, you can substitute with quick oats, but note that the texture will be slightly different. To enhance flavor, consider toasting the oats in a dry skillet for a few minutes before adding them to the mixture.

all-purpose flour

You can substitute whole wheat flour for a nuttier flavor and added fiber, but the cookies might be denser. If gluten-free is needed, use a gluten-free all-purpose flour blend, but check for xanthan gum in the blend to help with texture.

brown sugar

Light or dark brown sugar can be used interchangeably, with dark brown sugar providing a richer flavor due to the higher molasses content. If you need a substitute, you can use white sugar with an additional tablespoon of molasses for a similar taste.

ground ginger

If you prefer a fresher flavor, you can use freshly grated ginger, but reduce the amount to about 1 tablespoon since fresh ginger is more potent. If you don’t have ground ginger, try substituting with equal parts ground cinnamon or allspice for a different flavor profile.

ground cinnamon

For enhanced flavor, consider using Ceylon cinnamon, which is sweeter and more aromatic than the common Cassia cinnamon. If you like a spicier kick, you can add a pinch of nutmeg as well.

baking soda

Make sure your baking soda is fresh for the best rise. If you don’t have baking soda, you can substitute it with baking powder, but you will need to increase the amount to about 3 teaspoons.

salt

A small amount of salt enhances the flavors of the cookies. If you're watching sodium intake, you can reduce the salt, but don't omit it entirely. For a flavor twist, try using sea salt or pink Himalayan salt.

unsalted butter, softened

If you're out of unsalted butter, you can substitute with an equal amount of margarine or coconut oil, though this may alter the flavor slightly. For a richer taste, use browned butter, which adds a nutty flavor profile.

egg

If you need an egg substitute for vegan cookies, consider using 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce or a flax egg (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 2.5 tablespoons water, let sit for a few minutes).

molasses

Blackstrap molasses is more bitter and less sweet than regular molasses, so make sure to use light or regular molasses for a balanced flavor. If you don’t have molasses, you can substitute with honey or maple syrup, but the flavor will change slightly.

vanilla extract

For a stronger vanilla flavor, you can use vanilla bean paste, which has a more intense flavor and adds specks of vanilla bean. If you're out of vanilla extract, you can use almond extract as a substitute, but use it sparingly as it has a stronger flavor.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Start by preheating your oven to 350°F (175°C). This ensures that your cookies bake evenly and gives them that delightful golden brown color.

  • Step 2: Cream Butter and Sugar

    In a large mixing bowl, cream together 1/2 cup of softened unsalted butter with 3/4 cup of brown sugar using a hand mixer or a whisk. Beat until the mixture is light and fluffy, which usually takes about 2-3 minutes.

  • Step 3: Add Wet Ingredients

    Crack in 1 large egg, pour in 1/4 cup of molasses, and add 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Mix well until everything is fully combined. The mixture should be smooth and slightly thick.

  • Step 4: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a separate bowl, whisk together 2 cups of rolled oats, 1 cup of all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon, 1 teaspoon of baking soda, and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. This step ensures that the baking soda and spices are evenly distributed throughout the flour.

  • Step 5: Combine Wet and Dry Mixtures

    Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture. Stir gently until just combined; do not overmix as this might make the cookies tough.

  • Step 6: Prepare Baking Sheet

    Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Use a spoon or cookie scoop to drop spoonfuls of dough onto the prepared baking sheet, keeping them about 2 inches apart to allow for spreading during baking.

  • Step 7: Bake the Cookies

    Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges of the cookies are golden brown. Keep an eye on them to prevent burning!

  • Step 8: Cool the Cookies

    Once baked, let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes. This helps them firm up before transferring. After 5 minutes, transfer them to a wire rack to cool completely.

Frequently Asked Questions

What are rolled oats and can I use instant oats instead?

Rolled oats are whole oats that have been steamed and then flattened. They absorb liquid well and give cookies a chewy texture. Instant oats can be used, but they may lead to a different texture. If using instant oats, reduce the baking time slightly.

How do I know when my butter is softened?

Softened butter should be at room temperature. You can test it by pressing your finger into it; it should leave an indentation but not be melted. If you forget to take it out of the fridge, you can cut it into small pieces to speed up the softening process.

What is the purpose of molasses in these cookies?

Molasses adds moisture, flavor, and a slight chewiness to the cookies. It also contributes to their rich color and gingerbread taste. If you don’t have molasses, you can substitute with honey or maple syrup, but the flavor will be different.

How should I measure my flour and sugar?

To measure flour, spoon it into your measuring cup and level it off with a knife. For brown sugar, pack it firmly into the cup before leveling it off. This ensures accurate measurements for better results.

Why do I need to let the cookies cool before transferring them?

Cooling them on the baking sheet allows the cookies to firm up a bit, making them less likely to break when you move them. If you transfer them too soon, they may fall apart.

What does it mean to 'cream' the butter and sugar?

Creaming is the process of beating softened butter and sugar together until the mixture is light and fluffy. This incorporates air, which helps the cookies rise and gives them a lighter texture.

How do I know when the cookies are done baking?

The cookies are done when the edges are golden brown and the centers look slightly underbaked. They will continue to cook a bit as they cool.

Can I add nuts or chocolate chips to the cookie dough?

Absolutely! Feel free to add about 1/2 to 1 cup of chopped nuts or chocolate chips to the dough for extra flavor and texture.

How should I store the cookies once they are cool?

Store the cookies in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week. To keep them fresh, you can also freeze them in a freezer-safe container for up to 3 months.

What can I do if I don’t have parchment paper?

If you don’t have parchment paper, you can lightly grease the baking sheet with butter or cooking spray to prevent sticking. Alternatively, you can use a silicone baking mat.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a gluten-free version, substitute the all-purpose flour with a gluten-free flour blend. To make them dairy-free, replace the unsalted butter with coconut oil or a dairy-free butter substitute, and ensure that the chocolate or any mix-ins are dairy-free. These cookies can also be made vegan by using a flax egg (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 2.5 tablespoons water) in place of the egg and using a vegan butter substitute.

Pairings

Pair these Gingerbread Oatmeal Cookies with a warm spiced chai tea or a glass of cold milk for a comforting treat. For an adult twist, consider serving with a spiced rum cocktail or a hot apple cider to complement the warm spices in the cookies. These cookies also go well with a scoop of vanilla ice cream for a delightful dessert.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Gingerbread Oatmeal Cookies on a festive platter, perhaps dusted lightly with powdered sugar for a decorative touch. For a cozy gathering, present them alongside a selection of other holiday cookies and treats. Consider wrapping some cookies in cellophane with a ribbon for a charming homemade gift. To enhance the flavors, try adding a small dish of honey or spiced cream cheese dip on the side for dipping.

Gingerbread Oatmeal Cookies

30 min
$6
100 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 24

Allergens:

GlutenEggs

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianNut-free

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Dessert

Tags:

CookiesDessertEasyQuick

Description

Warm, chewy cookies with the comforting flavors of gingerbread and a hearty oatmeal texture.

Ingredients

  • rolled oats: 2 cups
  • all-purpose flour: 1 cup
  • brown sugar: 3/4 cup
  • ground ginger: 1 teaspoon
  • ground cinnamon: 1 teaspoon
  • baking soda: 1 teaspoon
  • salt: 1/2 teaspoon
  • unsalted butter, softened: 1/2 cup
  • egg: 1 large
  • molasses: 1/4 cup
  • vanilla extract: 1 teaspoon
